verses.textEn: The burden of Babylon which Isaiah, the son of Amoz, saw.
verses.textLa: Onus Babylonis, quod vidit Isaias filius Amos.

verses.textEn: Over the foggy mountain lift up a sign! Raise the voice, lift up the hand, and let the rulers enter through the gates!
verses.textLa: Super montem caliginosum levate signum, exaltate vocem, levate manum, et ingrediantur portas duces.

verses.textEn: In my wrath, I commanded my sanctified ones, and I called my strong ones, those who exult in my glory.
verses.textLa: Ego mandavi sanctificatis meis, et vocavi fortes meos in ira mea, exultantes in gloria mea.

verses.textEn: On the mountains, there is the voice of a multitude, as if of a numerous people, a voice with the sound of kings, of nations gathered together. For the Lord of hosts has given orders to soldiers of war,
verses.textLa: Vox multitudinis in montibus, quasi populorum frequentium: vox sonitus regum, gentium congregatarum: Dominus exercituum præcepit militiæ belli,

verses.textEn: to those who are arriving from a far off land, from the heights of the heavens. It is the Lord and the instruments of his fury, so that he may bring ruin to all the earth.
verses.textLa: venientibus de terra procul, a summitate cæli: Dominus, et vasa furoris eius, ut disperdat omnem terram.

verses.textEn: Wail aloud! For the day of the Lord draws near! It will arrive like a devastation from the Lord.
verses.textLa: Ululate, quia prope est dies Domini: quasi vastitas a Domino veniet.

verses.textEn: Because of it, every hand will fail, and every heart of man will waste away and be crushed.
verses.textLa: Propter hoc, omnes manus dissolventur, et omne cor hominis contabescet, et conteretur.

verses.textEn: Writhing and pain will seize them. They will be in pain, like a woman in labor. Each one will appear stupefied to his neighbor. Their countenances will be like faces which have been burned up.
verses.textLa: Torsiones et dolores tenebunt, quasi parturiens, dolebunt: unusquisque ad proximum suum stupebit, facies combustæ vultus eorum.

verses.textEn: Behold, the day of the Lord approaches: a cruel day, full of indignation and wrath and fury, which will place the earth in solitude and crush the sinners from it.
verses.textLa: Ecce dies Domini veniet, crudelis, et indignationis plenus, et iræ, furorisque ad ponendam terram in solitudinem, et peccatores eius conterendos de ea.

verses.textEn: For the stars of the heavens, in their splendor, will not display their light. The sun will be obscured at its rising, and the moon will not shine in her brightness.
verses.textLa: Quoniam stellæ cæli, et splendor earum non expandent lumen suum: obtenebratus est sol in ortu suo, et luna non splendebit in lumine suo.

verses.textEn: And I will act against the evils of the world, and against the impious for their iniquity. And I will cause the pride of the unfaithful to cease, and I will bring down the arrogance of the strong.
verses.textLa: Et visitabo super orbis mala, et contra impios iniquitatem eorum, et quiscere faciam superbiam infidelium, et arrogantiam fortium humiliabo.

verses.textEn: A man will be more precious than gold, and mankind will become like pure refined gold.
verses.textLa: Pretiosior erit vir auro, et homo mundo obrizo.

verses.textEn: For this purpose, I will stir up heaven, and the earth will be moved from its place, because of the indignation of the Lord of hosts, because of the day of his furious wrath.
verses.textLa: Super hoc cælum turbabo: et movebitur terra de loco suo propter indignationem Domini exercituum, et propter diem iræ furoris eius.

verses.textEn: And they will be like a doe fleeing away, or like sheep; and there will be no one who may gather them together. Each one will turn to his own people, and every one will flee to his own land.
verses.textLa: Et erit quasi damula fugiens, et quasi ovis: et non erit qui congreget: unusquisque ad populum suum convertetur, et singuli ad terram suam fugient.

verses.textEn: All who are found will be killed, and all who are caught unaware will fall by the sword.
verses.textLa: Omnis, qui inventus fuerit, occidetur: et omnis, qui supervenerit, cadet in gladio.

verses.textEn: Their infants will be thrown down violently before their eyes. Their houses will be plundered, and their wives will be violated.
verses.textLa: Infantes eorum allidentur in oculis eorum: diripientur domus eorum, et uxores eorum violabuntur.

verses.textEn: Behold, I will stir up the Medes against them. They will not seek silver, nor desire gold.
verses.textLa: Ecce ego suscitabo super eos Medos, qui argentum non quærant, nec aurum velint:

verses.textEn: Instead, with their arrows, they will put the little children to death, and they will take no pity on breastfeeding women, and their eye will not spare their children.
verses.textLa: sed sagittis parvulos interficient, et lactantibus uteris non miserebuntur, et super filios non parcet oculus eorum.

verses.textEn: And then Babylon, the glorious one among kingdoms, that famous pride of the Chaldeans, will be destroyed, even as the Lord destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah.
verses.textLa: Et erit Babylon illa gloriosa in regnis, inclyta superbia Chaldæorum: sicut subvertit Dominus Sodomam et Gomorrham.

verses.textEn: It will not be inhabited, even unto the end, and it will not be reestablished, even from generation to generation. The Arab will not pitch his tents there, nor will the shepherds take rest there.
verses.textLa: Non habitabitur usque in finem, et non fundabitur usque ad generationem et generationem: nec ponet ibi tentoria Arabs, nec pastores requiescent ibi.

verses.textEn: Instead, the wild beasts will rest there, and their houses will be filled with serpents, and ostriches will live there, and the hairy ones will leap about there.
verses.textLa: Sed requiescent ibi bestiæ, et replebuntur domus eorum draconibus: et habitabunt ibi struthiones, et pilosi saltabunt ibi:

verses.textEn: And the tawny owls will answer one another there, in its buildings, and the Sirens in its shrines of pleasure.
verses.textLa: et respondebunt ibi ululæ in ædibus eius, et sirenes in delubris voluptatis.

verses.textEn: Her time is drawing near, and her days will not be prolonged. For the Lord will take pity on Jacob, and he will still choose from Israel, and he will cause them to rest upon their own soil. And the new arrival will be joined to them, and he will adhere to the house of Jacob.
verses.textLa: Prope est ut veniat tempus eius, et dies eius non elongabuntur. Miserebitur enim Dominus Iacob, et eliget adhuc de Israel, et requiescere eos faciet super humum suam: adiungetur advena ad eos, et adhærebit domui Iacob.

verses.textEn: And the people will take them, and lead them to their place. And the house of Israel will possess them, in the land of the Lord, as men and women servants. And they will take captive those who had taken them captive. And they will subjugate their oppressors.
verses.textLa: Et tenebunt eos populi, et adducent eos in locum suum: et possidebit eos domus Israel super terram Domini in servos et ancillas: et erunt capientes eos, qui se ceperant, et subiicient exactores suos.

verses.textEn: And this shall be in that day: when God will have given you rest from your labor, and from your oppression, and from the difficult servitude under which you served before,
verses.textLa: Et erit in die illa: cum requiem dederit tibi Deus a labore tuo, et a concussione tua, et a servitute dura, qua ante servisti:

verses.textEn: you will accept this parable against the king of Babylon, and you will say: “How is it that the oppressor has ceased, along with his tribute?
verses.textLa: sumes parabolam istam contra regem Babylonis, et dices: Quomodo cessavit exactor, quievit tributum?

verses.textEn: The Lord has crushed the staff of the impious, the scepter of despots,
verses.textLa: Contrivit Dominus baculum impiorum, virgam dominantium,

verses.textEn: which struck the people in wrath with an incurable wound, which subjugated the nations in fury, which persecuted with cruelty.
verses.textLa: cædentem populos in indignatione, plaga insanabili, subiicientem in furore gentes, persequentem crudeliter.

verses.textEn: All the earth has become quiet and still; it has been gladdened and has rejoiced.
verses.textLa: Conquievit et siluit omnis terra, gavisa est et exultavit:

verses.textEn: The evergreens, too, have rejoiced over you, and the cedars of Lebanon, saying: ‘Since you have slept, no one has ascended who would cut us down.’
verses.textLa: abietes quoque lætatæ sunt super te, et cedri Libani: ex quo dormisti, non ascendet qui succidat nos.

verses.textEn: Hell below was stirred up to meet you at your advent; it has awakened the giants for you. All the leaders of the earth have risen from their thrones, all the leaders among the nations.”
verses.textLa: Infernus subter conturbatus est in occursum adventus tui, suscitavit tibi gigantes. Omnes principes terræ surrexerunt de soliis suis, omnes principes nationum.

verses.textEn: Everyone will respond and will say to you: “Now you are wounded, just as we were; you have become like us.
verses.textLa: Universi respondebunt, et dicent tibi: Et tu vulneratus es sicut et nos, nostri similis effectus es.

verses.textEn: Your arrogance has been dragged down to Hell. Your body has fallen dead. The moths will be strewn beneath you, and the worms will be your covering.
verses.textLa: Detracta est ad inferos superbia tua, concidit cadaver tuum: subter te sternetur tinea, et operimentum tuum erunt vermes.

verses.textEn: How is it that you have fallen from heaven, O Lucifer, who used to rise like the sun? How is it that you have fallen to the earth, you who wounded the peoples?
verses.textLa: Quomodo cecidisti de cælo Lucifer, qui mane oriebaris? Corruisti in terram, qui vulnerabas gentes?

verses.textEn: And you said in your heart: ‘I will climb up to heaven. I will exalt my throne above the stars of God. I will be enthroned upon the mountain of the covenant, on the northern parts.
verses.textLa: Qui dicebas in corde tuo: In cælum conscendam, super astra Dei exaltabo solium meum, sedebo in monte testamenti, in lateribus Aquilonis,

verses.textEn: I will ascend above the tops of the clouds. I will be like the Most High.’
verses.textLa: Ascendam super altitudinem nubium, similis ero Altissimo.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, you shall be dragged down to Hell, into the depths of the pit.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen ad infernum detraheris in profundum laci:

verses.textEn: Those who see you, will lean toward you, and will gaze upon you, saying: ‘Could this be the man who disturbed the earth, who shook kingdoms,
verses.textLa: qui te viderint, ad te inclinabuntur, teque prospicient: Numquid iste est vir, qui conturbavit terram, qui concussit regna,

verses.textEn: who made the world into a desert and destroyed its cities, who would not even open a prison for his prisoners?’ ”
verses.textLa: qui posuit orbem desertum, et urbes eius destruxit, vinctis eius non aperuit carcerem?

verses.textEn: All the kings of the nations throughout the whole world have slept in glory, each man in his own house.
verses.textLa: Omnes reges gentium universi dormierunt in gloria, vir in domo sua.

verses.textEn: But you have been rejected from your grave, like a useless polluted plant, and you have been bound up with those who were slain by the sword, and who descended to the bottom of the pit, like a rotting carcass.
verses.textLa: Tu autem proiectus es de sepulchro tuo, quasi stirps inutilis pollutus, et obvolutus cum his, qui interfecti sunt gladio, et descenderunt ad fundamenta laci, quasi cadaver putridum.

verses.textEn: You will not be associated with them, even in the grave. For you have destroyed your own land; you have slain your own people. The offspring of the wicked ones will not be called upon for eternity.
verses.textLa: Non habebis consortium, neque cum eis in sepultura: tu enim terram tuam disperdidisti, tu populum tuum occidisti: non vocabitur in æternum semen pessimorum.

verses.textEn: Prepare his sons for the slaughter, according to the iniquity of their fathers. They will not rise up, nor inherit the earth, nor fill the face of the world with cities.
verses.textLa: Præparate filios eius occisioni in iniquitate patrum suorum: non consurgent, nec hereditabunt terram, neque implebunt faciem orbis civitatum.

verses.textEn: But I will rise up against them, says the Lord of hosts. And I will perish the name of Babylon and its remnants: both the plant and its progeny, says the Lord.
verses.textLa: Et consurgam super eos, dicit Dominus exercituum: et perdam Babylonis nomen, et reliquias, et germen, et progeniem, dicit Dominus.

verses.textEn: And I will appoint it as a possession for the hedgehog, with swamps of water. And I will sweep it out and wear it away with a brush, says the Lord of hosts.
verses.textLa: Et ponam eam in possessionem ericii, et in paludes aquarum, et scopabo eam in scopa terens, dicit Dominus exercituum.

verses.textEn: The Lord of hosts has sworn, saying: Surely, just as I have considered it, so shall it be, and in the same manner as I have drawn it through my mind,
verses.textLa: Iuravit Dominus exercituum, dicens: Si non, ut putavi, ita erit: et quo modo mente tractavi,

verses.textEn: so shall it occur. So shall I crush the Assyrian in my land, and I will trample him upon my mountains, and his yoke will be taken away from them, and his burden will be removed from their shoulder.
verses.textLa: sic eveniet: Ut conteram Assyrium in terra mea, et in montibus meis conculcem eum: et auferetur ab eis iugum eius, et onus illius ab humero eorum tolletur.

verses.textEn: This is the plan that I have decided, concerning the entire earth, and this is the hand which is extended over all the nations.
verses.textLa: Hoc consilium, quod cogitavi super omnem terram, et hæc est manus extenta super universas gentes.

verses.textEn: For the Lord of hosts has decreed it, and who is able to weaken it? And his hand is extended, so who can avert it?
verses.textLa: Dominus enim exercituum decrevit: et quis poterit infirmare? Et manus eius extenta: et quis avertet eam?

verses.textEn: In the year in which king Ahaz died, this burden was given:
verses.textLa: In anno, quo mortuus est rex Achaz, factum est onus istud:

verses.textEn: You should not rejoice, all you of Philistia, that the rod of him who struck you has been crushed. For from the root of the serpent will go forth a king snake, and his offspring will engulf that which flies.
verses.textLa: ne lætaris Philisthæa omnis tu, quoniam comminuta est virga percussoris tui: de radice enim colubri egredietur regulus, et semen eius absorbens volucrem.

verses.textEn: And the firstborn of the poor will be pastured, and the poor will rest in faithfulness. And I will cause your root to pass away by famine, and I will put to death your remnant.
verses.textLa: Et pascentur primogeniti pauperum, et pauperes fiducialiter requiescent: et interire faciam in fame radicem tuam, et reliquias tuas interficiam.

verses.textEn: Wail, O gate! Cry out, O city! All of Philistia has been prostrated. For a smoke will arrive from the north, and there is no one who will escape his army.
verses.textLa: Ulula porta, clama civitas: prostrata est Philisthæa omnis: ab Aquilone enim fumus veniet, et non est qui effugiet agmen eius.

verses.textEn: And what will be the response to this news among the nations? It will be that the Lord has established Zion, and that the poor of his people will hope in him.
verses.textLa: Et quid respondebitur nunciis gentis? Quia Dominus fundavit Sion, et in ipso sperabunt pauperes populi eius.

verses.textEn: The burden of Moab. Because Ar of Moab has been destroyed by night, it is utterly silent. Because the wall of Moab has been destroyed by night, it is utterly silent.
verses.textLa: Onus Moab. Quia nocte vastata est Ar Moab, conticuit: quia nocte vastatus est murus Moab, conticuit.
verses.notes: The ‘con’ prefix intensifies the meaning of the verb, hence the translation “utterly silent.”

verses.textEn: The house has ascended with Dibon to the heights, in mourning over Nebo and over Medeba. Moab has wailed. There will be baldness on all of their heads, and every beard will be shaven.
verses.textLa: Ascendit domus, et Dibon ad excelsa in planctum super Nabo, et super Medaba, Moab ululavit: in cunctis capitibus eius calvitium, et omnis barba radetur.

verses.textEn: At their crossroads, they have been wrapped with sackcloth. On their rooftops and in their streets, everyone descends, wailing and weeping.
verses.textLa: In triviis eius accincti sunt sacco: super tecta eius, et in plateis eius omnis ululatus descendit in fletum.

verses.textEn: Heshbon will cry out with Elealeh. Their voice has been heard as far as Jahaz. Over this, the well-equipped men of Moab wail; each soul will wail to itself.
verses.textLa: Clamabit Hesebon, et Eleale, usque Iasa audita est vox eorum. Super hoc expediti Moab ululabunt, anima eius ululabit sibi.

verses.textEn: My heart will cry out to Moab; its bars will cry out even to Zoar, like a three-year-old calf. For they will ascend weeping, by way of the ascent of Luhith. And along the way of Horonaim, they will lift up a cry of contrition.
verses.textLa: Cor meum ad Moab clamabit, vectes eius usque ad Segor vitulam conternantem: per ascensum enim Luith flens ascendet, et in via Oronaim clamorem contritionis levabunt.

verses.textEn: For the waters of Nimrim will be desolate, because the plants have withered, and the seedling has failed, and all the greenery has passed away.
verses.textLa: Aquæ enim Nemrim desertæ erunt, quia aruit herba, defecit germen, viror omnis interiit.

verses.textEn: This is in accord with the magnitude of their works and of their visitation. They will lead them to the torrent of the willows.
verses.textLa: Secundum magnitudinem operis et visitatio eorum: ad torrentem salicum ducent eos.

verses.textEn: For an outcry has circulated along the border of Moab; its wailing even to Eglaim, and its clamor even to the well of Elim.
verses.textLa: Quoniam circuivit clamor terminum Moab: usque ad Gallim ululatus eius, et usque ad Puteum Elim clamor eius.

verses.textEn: Because the waters of Dibon have been filled with blood, I will place even more upon Dibon: those from Moab who flee the lion, and the survivors of the earth.
verses.textLa: Quia aquæ Dibon repletæ sunt sanguine: ponam enim super Dibon additamenta: his, qui fugerint de Moab leonem, et reliquiis terræ.

verses.textEn: O Lord, send forth the Lamb, the Ruler of the earth, from the Rock of the desert to the mountain of the daughter of Zion.
verses.textLa: Emitte agnum Domine dominatorem terræ, de Petra deserti ad montem filiæ Sion.

verses.textEn: And this shall be: like a bird fleeing away, and like fledglings flying from the nest, so will the daughters of Moab be at the passage of Arnon.
verses.textLa: Et erit: Sicut avis fugiens, et pulli de nido avolantes, sic erunt filiæ Moab in transcensu Arnon.

verses.textEn: Form a plan. Call a council. Let your shadow be as if it were night, even at midday. Conceal the fugitives, and do not betray the wanderers.
verses.textLa: Ini consilium, coge concilium: pone quasi noctem umbram tuam in meridie. Absconde fugientes, et vagos ne prodas.

verses.textEn: My fugitives will live with you. Become a hiding place, O Moab, from the face of the destroyer. For the dust is at its end; the miserable one has been consumed. He who trampled the earth has failed.
verses.textLa: Habitabunt apud te profugi mei: Moab esto latibulum eorum a facie vastatoris: finitus est enim pulvis, consummatus est miser: defecit qui conculcabat terram.

verses.textEn: And a throne will be prepared in mercy, and One shall sit upon it in truth, in the tabernacle of David, judging and seeking judgment, and quickly repaying what is just.
verses.textLa: Et præparabitur in misericordia solium, et sedebit super illud in veritate in tabernaculo David, iudicans et quærens iudicium, et velociter reddens quod iustum est.

verses.textEn: We have heard of the pride of Moab; he is very proud. His pride and his arrogance and his indignation is more than his strength.
verses.textLa: Audivimus superbiam Moab, superbus est valde: superbia eius et arrogantia eius, et indignatio eius plusquam fortitudo eius.

verses.textEn: For this reason, Moab will wail to Moab; each one will wail. Speak of their wounds to those who rejoice upon the brick walls.
verses.textLa: Idcirco ululabit Moab ad Moab, universus ululabit: his, qui lætantur super muros cocti lateris, loquimini plagas suas.

verses.textEn: For the suburbs of Heshbon are deserted, and the lords of the Gentiles have cut down the vineyard of Sibmah. Its vines have arrived even at Jazer. They have wandered in the desert. Its seedlings have been abandoned. They have crossed over the sea.
verses.textLa: Quoniam suburbana Hesebon deserta sunt, et vineam Sabama domini Gentium exciderunt: flagella eius usque ad Iazer pervenerunt: erraverunt in deserto, propagines eius relictæ sunt, transierunt mare.

verses.textEn: I will weep with the tears of Jazer over this, the vineyard of Sibmah. I will inebriate you with my tears, Heshbon and Elealeh! For the sound of those who trample has rushed over your vintage and over your harvest.
verses.textLa: Super hoc plorabo in fletu Iazer vineam Sabama: inebriabo de lacryma mea Hesebon, et Eleale: quoniam super vindemiam tuam, et super messem tuam vox calcantium irruit.

verses.textEn: And so, rejoicing and exultation will be taken away from Carmel, and there will be no jubilation or exultation in the vineyards. He who was accustomed to tread will not tread out the wine in the winepress. I have taken away the sound of those who tread.
verses.textLa: Et auferetur lætitia et exultatio de Carmelo, et in vineis non exultabit neque iubilabit. Vinum in torculari non calcabit qui calcare consueverat: vocem calcantium abstuli.

verses.textEn: Over this, my heart will resonate like a harp for Moab, and my inner most being for the brick wall.
verses.textLa: Super hoc venter meus ad Moab quasi cithara sonabit, et viscera mea ad murum cocti lateris.

verses.textEn: And this shall be: when it is seen that Moab has struggled upon his high places, he will enter his holy places to pray, but he will not prevail.
verses.textLa: Et erit: cum apparuerit quod laboravit Moab super excelsis suis, ingredietur ad sancta sua ut obsecret, et non valebit.

verses.textEn: This is the word that the Lord has spoken to Moab concerning that time.
verses.textLa: Hoc verbum, quod locutus est Dominus ad Moab ex tunc:

verses.textEn: And now the Lord has spoken, saying: In three years, like the years of a hired hand, the glory of Moab concerning the entire multitude of the people will be taken away, and what is left behind will be small and weak and not so numerous.
verses.textLa: et nunc locutus est Dominus, dicens: In tribus annis quasi anni mercenarii auferetur gloria Moab super omni populo multo, et relinquetur parvus et modicus, nequaquam multus.

verses.textEn: The burden of Damascus. Behold, Damascus will cease to be a city, and it will be like a heap of stones in ruin.
verses.textLa: Onus Damasci. Ecce Damascus desinet esse civitas, et erit sicut acervus lapidum in ruina.

verses.textEn: The cities in ruin will be left for the flocks, and they will take rest there, and there will be no one who may terrify them.
verses.textLa: Derelictæ civitates Aroer gregibus erunt, et requiescent ibi, et non erit qui exterreat.

verses.textEn: And assistance will cease from Ephraim, and the kingdom will cease from Damascus. And the remnant of Syria will be like the glory of the sons of Israel, says the Lord of hosts.
verses.textLa: Et cessabit adiutorium ab Ephraim, et regnum a Damasco: et reliquiæ Syriæ sicut gloria filiorum Israel erunt: dicit Dominus exercituum.

verses.textEn: And this shall be in that day: the glory of Jacob will be thinned, and the fatness of his flesh will be reduced.
verses.textLa: Et erit in die illa: attenuabitur gloria Iacob, et pinguedo carnis eius marcescet.

verses.textEn: And it shall be like the gathering of the harvest which remains, and his arm will pick the ears of grain. And it shall be like a search for grain in the valley of Rephaim.
verses.textLa: Et erit sicut congregans in messe quod restiterit, et brachium eius spicas leget: et erit sicut quærens spicas in valle Raphaim.

verses.textEn: And what is left behind in it will be like one cluster of grapes, or like a shaken olive tree with two or three olives at the top of a branch, or like four or five olives at the top of a tree, says the Lord God of Israel.
verses.textLa: Et relinquetur in eo sicut racemus, et sicut excussio oleæ duarum vel trium olivarum in summitate rami, sive quattuor aut quinque in cacuminibus eius fructus eius: dicit Dominus Deus Israel.

verses.textEn: In that day, a man will bow before his Maker, and his eyes will consider the Holy One of Israel.
verses.textLa: In die illa inclinabitur homo ad Factorem suum, et oculi eius ad Sanctum Israel respicient:

verses.textEn: And he will not bow before the altars that his hands have made. And he will not consider the things that his fingers have made, the sacred groves and the shrines.
verses.textLa: et non inclinabitur ad altaria, quæ fecerunt manus eius: et quæ operati sunt digiti eius non respiciet, lucos et delubra.

verses.textEn: In that day, his strong cities will be abandoned, like the plows and the grain fields which were left behind before the face of the sons of Israel, and you shall be deserted.
verses.textLa: In die illa erunt civitates fortitudinis eius derelictæ sicut aratra, et segetes quæ derelictæ sunt a facie filiorum Israel, et eris deserta.

verses.textEn: For you have forgotten God your Savior, and you have not remembered your strong Helper. Because of this, you will plant trustworthy plants, but you will sow a foreign seed.
verses.textLa: Quia oblitus es Dei Salvatoris tui, et fortis Adiutoris tui non es recordata: propterea plantabis plantationem fidelem, et germen alienum seminabis.

verses.textEn: In the day of your planting, the wild grapevine and your morning seed will flourish. The harvest has been taken away to the day of inheritance, and you will grieve heavily.
verses.textLa: In die plantationis tuæ labrusca, et mane semen tuum florebit: ablata est messis in die hereditatis, et dolebit graviter.

verses.textEn: Woe to the multitude of many peoples, like the multitude of the roaring sea! Woe to the tumult of crowds, like the noise of many waters!
verses.textLa: Væ multitudini populorum multorum, ut multitudo maris sonantis: et tumultus turbarum, sicut sonitus aquarum multarum.

verses.textEn: The peoples will make a noise, like the noise of waters overflowing, but he will rebuke him, and so he will flee far away. And he will be quickly taken away, like the dust of the mountains before the face of the wind, and like a whirlwind before a tempest.
verses.textLa: Sonabunt populi sicut sonitus aquarum inundantium, et increpabit eum, et fugiet procul: et rapietur sicut pulvis montium a facie venti, et sicut turbo coram tempestate.

verses.textEn: In the time of the evening, behold: there will be a disturbance. When it is early morning, he will not remain. This is the portion of those who have devastated us, and this is the lot of those who have plundered us.
verses.textLa: In tempore vespere, et ecce turbatio: in matutino, et non subsistet. Hæc est pars eorum, qui vastaverunt nos, et sors diripientium nos.

verses.textEn: Woe to the land, that winged cymbal, which is beyond the rivers of Ethiopia,
verses.textLa: Væ terræ cymbalo alarum, quæ est trans flumina Æthiopiæ,

verses.textEn: which sends ambassadors by sea and in vessels of papyrus above the waters. Go forth, O swift Angels, to a nation which has been convulsed and torn apart, to a terrible people, after whom there is no other, to a nation apprehensive and downtrodden, whose land the rivers have spoiled.
verses.textLa: qui mittit in mare legatos, et in vasis papyri super aquas. Ite Angeli veloces ad gentem convulsam, et dilaceratam: ad populum terribilem, post quem non est alius: ad gentem expectantem et conculcatam, cuius diripuerunt flumina terram eius:
verses.notes: In this context, ‘expectantem’ has a negative connotation, so it refers to apprehension rather than hopeful expectation.

verses.textEn: All inhabitants of the world, you who dwell upon the earth: when the sign will have been elevated on the mountains, you will see, and you will hear the blast of the trumpet.
verses.textLa: omnes habitatores orbis, qui moramini in terra, cum elevatum fuerit signum in montibus, videbitis, et clangorem tubæ audietis:

verses.textEn: For the Lord says this to me: I will be quiet, and I will consider in my place, as the light at midday is clear, and as a cloud of dew in the day of the harvest.
verses.textLa: quia hæc dicit Dominus ad me: Quiescam, et considerabo in loco meo sicut meridiana lux clara est, et sicut nubes roris in die messis.

verses.textEn: For before the harvest, all was flourishing. And it will spring forth with an untimely completion, and its little branches will be pruned with a curved blade. And what is left over will be cut away and shaken off.
verses.textLa: Ante messem enim totus effloruit, et immatura perfectio germinabit, et præcidentur ramusculi eius falcibus: et quæ derelicta fuerint, abscindentur, et excutientur.

verses.textEn: And together they will be abandoned to the birds of the mountains and to the wild beasts of the earth. And the birds will be continuously on them in the summer, and all the wild beasts of the earth will winter over them.
verses.textLa: Et relinquentur simul avibus montium, et bestiis terræ: et æstate perpetua erunt super eum volucres, et omnes bestiæ terræ super illum hiemabunt.

verses.textEn: In that time, a gift will be carried to the Lord of hosts, from a people divided and torn apart, from a terrible people, after whom there has been no other, from an apprehensive nation, apprehensive and downtrodden, whose land the rivers have ruined, and it will be carried to the place of the name of the Lord of hosts, to mount Zion.
verses.textLa: In tempore illo deferetur munus Domino exercituum a populo divulso et dilacerato: a populo terribili, post quem non fuit alius, a gente expectante, expectante et conculcata, cuius diripuerunt flumina terram eius, ad locum nominis Domini exercituum montem Sion.

verses.textEn: The burden of Egypt. Behold, the Lord will ascend upon a lofty cloud, and he will enter into Egypt, and the false images of Egypt will be moved before his face, and the heart of Egypt will waste away in its midst.
verses.textLa: Onus Ægypti. Ecce Dominus ascendet super nubem levem, et ingredietur Ægyptum, et commovebuntur simulachra Ægypti a facie eius, et cor Ægypti tabescet in medio eius.

verses.textEn: And I will cause Egyptian to rush against Egyptian. And they will fight: a man against his brother, and a man against his friend, city against city, kingdom against kingdom.
verses.textLa: Et concurrere faciam Ægyptios adversus Ægyptios: et pugnabit vir contra fratrem suum, et vir contra amicum suum, civitas adversus civitatem, regnum adversus regnum.

verses.textEn: And the spirit of Egypt will be ruptured to its very core. And I will cast down their plan violently. And they will seek answers from their false images, and their diviners, and those led by demons, and their seers.
verses.textLa: Et dirumpetur spiritus Ægypti in visceribus eius, et consilium eius præcipitabo: et interrogabunt simulachra sua, et divinos suos, et pythones, et ariolos.
verses.notes: The term ‘pythones’ refers to someone who is a seer by means of demonic assistance, like the false visionaries and false seers of the present time.

verses.textEn: And I will deliver Egypt into the hand of cruel masters, and a strong king will dominate them, says the Lord, the God of hosts.
verses.textLa: Et tradam Ægyptum in manu dominorum crudelium, et rex fortis dominabitur eorum, ait Dominus Deus exercituum.

verses.textEn: And the waters of the sea will dry up, and the river will be desolate and dry.
verses.textLa: Et arescet aqua de mari, et fluvius desolabitur, atque siccabitur.

verses.textEn: And the rivers will fail. The streams of its banks will diminish and dry up. The reed and the bulrush will wither away.
verses.textLa: Et deficient flumina: attenuabuntur, et siccabuntur rivi aggerum. Calamus et iuncus marcescet:

verses.textEn: The channel of the river will be stripped down to its source, and everything irrigated by it will dry up and wither and be no more.
verses.textLa: nudabitur alveus rivi a fonte suo, et omnis sementis irrigua siccabitur, arescet, et non erit.

verses.textEn: And the fishermen will grieve. And all who cast a hook into the river will mourn. And those who cast a net upon the surface of its waters will languish.
verses.textLa: Et mœrebunt piscatores, et lugebunt omnes mittentes in flumen hamum, et expandentes rete super faciem aquarum emarcescent.

verses.textEn: Those who work with linen, combing and weaving fine textiles, will be confounded.
verses.textLa: Confundentur qui operabantur linum, pectentes, et texentes subtilia.

verses.textEn: And its irrigated places will begin to fail, with all those who make pools to take fish.
verses.textLa: Et erunt irrigua eius flaccentia: omnes qui faciebant lacunas ad capiendos pisces.

verses.textEn: The leaders of Tanis are foolish. The wise counselors of Pharaoh have given foolish counsel. How can you say to Pharaoh: “I am the son of wise men, the son of the kings of antiquity?”
verses.textLa: Stulti principes Taneos, sapientes consiliarii Pharaonis dederunt consilium insipiens: quomodo dicetis Pharaoni: Filius sapientium ego, filius regum antiquorum?

verses.textEn: Where are your wise men now? Let them announce it to you, and let them reveal what the Lord of hosts intends for Egypt.
verses.textLa: Ubi nunc sunt sapientes tui? Annuncient tibi, et indicent quid cogitaverit Dominus exercituum super Ægyptum.

verses.textEn: The leaders of Tanis have become foolish. The leaders of Memphis have decayed. They have deceived Egypt, the corner of its people.
verses.textLa: Stulti facti sunt principes Taneos, emarcuerunt principes Mempheos, deceperunt Ægyptum, angulum populorum eius.

verses.textEn: The Lord has mixed a spirit of giddiness into its midst. And they have caused Egypt to err in all its works, like a drunken man who staggers and vomits.
verses.textLa: Dominus miscuit in medio eius spiritum vertiginis: et errare fecerunt Ægyptum in omni opere suo, sicut errat ebrius et vomens.

verses.textEn: And there will be no work for Egypt that would produce a head or a tail, one who bows down or one who refrains from bowing down.
verses.textLa: Et non erit Ægypto opus, quod faciat caput et caudam incurvantem, et refrenantem.

verses.textEn: In that day, Egypt will be like women, and they will be stupefied and fearful before the presence of the shaking hand of the Lord of hosts, the hand which he will move over them.
verses.textLa: In die illa erit Ægyptus quasi mulieres, et stupebunt, et timebunt a facie commotionis manus Domini exercituum, quam ipse movebit super eam.

verses.textEn: And the land of Judah will be a dread to Egypt. Everyone who thinks about it will be terrified before the presence of the plan of the Lord of hosts, the plan which he has decided concerning them.
verses.textLa: Et erit Terra Iuda Ægypto in pavorem: omnis, qui illius fuerit recordatus, pavebit a facie consilii Domini exercituum, quod ipse cogitavit super eam.

verses.textEn: In that day, there will be five cities in the land of Egypt which speak the language of Canaan, and which swear by the Lord of hosts. One will be called the City of the Sun.
verses.textLa: In die illa erunt quinque civitates in Terra Ægypti, loquentes lingua Chanaan, et iurantes per Dominum exercituum: Civitas solis vocabitur una.

verses.textEn: In that day, there will be an altar of the Lord in the midst of the land of Egypt and a monument of the Lord beside its borders.
verses.textLa: In die illa erit altare Domini in medio Terræ Ægypti, et titulus Domini iuxta terminum eius:

verses.textEn: This shall be a sign and a testimony to the Lord of hosts in the land of Egypt. For they will cry out to the Lord before the face of the tribulation, and he will send them a savior and a defender who will free them.
verses.textLa: erit in signum, et in testimonium Domino exercituum in Terra Ægypti. Clamabunt enim ad Dominum a facie tribulationis, et mittet eis salvatorem et propugnatorem, qui liberet eos.
verses.notes: This last part could refer to the great Catholic monarch, who reigns after the first part of the tribulation.

verses.textEn: And the Lord will be acknowledged by Egypt, and the Egyptians will recognize the Lord in that day, and they will worship him with sacrifices and gifts. And they will make vows to the Lord, and they will fulfill them.
verses.textLa: Et cognoscetur Dominus ab Ægypto, et cognoscent Ægyptii Dominum in die illa, et colent eum in hostiis et in muneribus: et vota vovebunt Domino, et solvent.

verses.textEn: And the Lord will strike Egypt with a scourge, and he will heal them. And they will return to the Lord. And he will be placated toward them, and he will heal them.
verses.textLa: Et percutiet Dominus Ægyptum plaga, et sanabit eam, et revertentur ad Dominum, et placabitur eis, et sanabit eos.

verses.textEn: In that day, there will be a way from Egypt to the Assyrians, and the Assyrian will enter into Egypt, and the Egyptian will be with the Assyrians, and the Egyptians will serve Assur.
verses.textLa: In die illa erit via de Ægypto in Assyrios, et intrabit Assyrius Ægyptum, et Ægyptius in Assyrios, et servient Ægyptii Assur.

verses.textEn: In that day, will Israel be the third to the Egyptian and the Assyrian, a blessing in the midst of the earth,
verses.textLa: In die illa erit Israel tertius Ægyptio et Assyrio: benedictio in medio terræ,

verses.textEn: which the Lord of hosts has blessed, saying: Blessed be my people of Egypt, and the work of my hands for the Assyrian, but Israel is my inheritance.
verses.textLa: cui benedixit Dominus exercituum, dicens: Benedictus populus meus Ægypti, et opus manuum mearum Assyrio: hereditas autem mea Israel.

verses.textEn: In the year in which Tharthan entered into Ashdod, when Sargon, the king of the Assyrians, had sent him, and when he had fought against Ashdod and had captured it,
verses.textLa: In anno, quo ingressus est Thathan in Azotum, cum misisset eum Sargon rex Assyriorum, et pugnasset contra Azotum, et cepisset eam:

verses.textEn: in that same time, the Lord spoke by the hand of Isaiah, the son of Amoz, saying: “Go forth, and remove the sackcloth from your waist, and take your shoes from your feet.” And he did so, going out naked and barefoot.
verses.textLa: in tempore illo locutus est Dominus in manu Isaiæ filii Amos, dicens: Vade, et solve saccum de lumbis tuis, et calceamenta tua tolle de pedibus tuis. Et fecit sic vadens nudus, et discalceatus.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said: Just as my servant Isaiah has walked naked and barefoot, as a sign and as a portent of three years over Egypt and over Ethiopia,
verses.textLa: Et dixit Dominus: Sicut ambulavit servus meus Isaias nudus, et discalceatus, trium annorum signum et portentum erit super Ægyptum, et super Æthiopiam,

verses.textEn: so also will the king of the Assyrians force the captivity of Egypt, and the transmigration of Ethiopia: young and old, naked and barefoot, with their buttocks uncovered, to the shame of Egypt.
verses.textLa: sic minabit rex Assyriorum captivitatem Ægypti, et transmigrationem Æthiopiæ, iuvenum et senum, nudam et discalceatam, discoopertis natibus ad ignominiam Ægypti.

verses.textEn: And they will be afraid and confounded over Ethiopia, their hope, and Egypt, their glory.
verses.textLa: Et timebunt, et confundentur ab Æthiopia spe sua, et ab Ægypto gloria sua.

verses.textEn: And in that day, the inhabitants of a certain island will say: “Behold, this was our hope, we fled to them for help, to free us from the face of the king of the Assyrians. And now, how will we be able to escape?”
verses.textLa: Et dicet habitator insulæ huius in die illa: Ecce hæc erat spes nostra, ad quos confugimus in auxilium, ut liberarent nos a facie regis Assyriorum: et quomodo effugere poterimus nos?

verses.textEn: The burden of the desert of the sea. Just as the whirlwinds approach from Africa, it approaches from the desert, from a terrible land.
verses.textLa: Onus deserti maris. Sicut turbines ab Africo veniunt, de deserto venit, de terra horribili.

verses.textEn: A difficult vision has been announced to me: he who is unbelieving, he acts unfaithfully, and he who is a plunderer, he devastates. Ascend, O Elam! Lay siege, O Media! I have caused all its mourning to cease.
verses.textLa: Visio dura nunciata est mihi: qui incredulus est, infideliter agit: et qui depopulator est, vastat. Ascende Ælam, obside Mede: omnem gemitum eius cessare feci.

verses.textEn: Because of this, my lower back has been filled with pain, and anguish has possessed me, like the anguish of a woman in labor. I fell down when I heard it. I was disturbed when I saw it.
verses.textLa: Propterea repleti sunt lumbi mei dolore, angustia possedit me sicut angustia parturientis: corrui cum audirem, conturbatus sum cum viderem.

verses.textEn: My heart withered. The darkness stupefied me. Babylon, my beloved, has become a wonder to me.
verses.textLa: Emarcuit cor meum, tenebræ stupefecerunt me: Babylon dilecta mea posita est mihi in miraculum.

verses.textEn: Prepare the table. Contemplate, from a place of observation, those who eat and drink. Rise up, you leaders! Take up the shield!
verses.textLa: Pone mensam, contemplare in specula comedentes et bibentes: surgite principes, arripite clypeum.

verses.textEn: For the Lord has said this to me: “Go and station a watchman. And let him announce whatever he will see.”
verses.textLa: Hæc enim dixit mihi Dominus: Vade, et pone speculatorem: et quodcumque viderit, annunciet.

verses.textEn: And he saw a chariot with two horsemen, and a rider on a donkey, and a rider on a camel. And he considered them diligently, with an intense gaze.
verses.textLa: Et vidit currum duorum equitum, ascensorem asini, et ascensorem cameli: et contemplatus est diligenter multo intuitu.

verses.textEn: And a lion cried out: “I am on the watchtower of the Lord, standing continually by day. And I am at my station, standing throughout the night.
verses.textLa: Et clamavit leo: Super speculam Domini ego sum, stans iugiter per diem: et super custodiam meam ego sum, stans totis noctibus.

verses.textEn: Behold, a certain man approaches, a man riding on a two-horse chariot.” And he responded, and he said: “Fallen, fallen is Babylon! And all its graven gods have been crushed into the earth!
verses.textLa: Ecce iste venit ascensor vir bigæ equitum, et respondit, et dixit: Cecidit, cecidit Babylon, et omnia sculptilia deorum eius contrita sunt in terram.

verses.textEn: O my threshed grain! O sons of my threshing floor! What I have heard from the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel, I have announced to you.”
verses.textLa: Tritura mea, et filii areæ meæ, quæ audivi a Domino exercituum Deo Israel, annunciavi vobis.

verses.textEn: The burden of Dumah, cried out to me from Seir: “Watchman, how goes the night? Watchman, how goes the night?”
verses.textLa: Onus Duma ad me clamat ex Seir: Custos quid de nocte? Custos quid de nocte?

verses.textEn: The watchman said: “Morning approaches with the night. If you are seeking: seek, and convert, and approach.”
verses.textLa: Dixit custos: Venit mane et nox: si quæritis, quærite: convertimini, venite.

verses.textEn: The burden in Arabia. In the forest you shall sleep, in the evening on the paths of Dedanim.
verses.textLa: Onus in Arabia. In saltu ad vesperam dormietis, in semitis Dedanim.

verses.textEn: You who inhabit the land of the south: upon meeting the thirsty, bring water; meet the fugitive with bread.
verses.textLa: Occurrentes sitienti ferte aquam, qui habitatis terram Austri, cum panibus occurrite fugienti.

verses.textEn: For they are fleeing before the face of swords, before the face of a sword hanging over them, before the face of a bent bow, before the face of a grievous battle.
verses.textLa: A facie enim gladiorum fugerunt, a facie gladii imminentis, a facie arcus extenti, a facie gravis prælii:

verses.textEn: For the Lord said this to me: “After one more year, just like one year for a hired hand, all the glory of Kedar will be taken away.
verses.textLa: quoniam hæc dicit Dominus ad me: Adhuc in uno anno, quasi in anno mercenarii, et auferetur omnis gloria Cedar.

verses.textEn: And the remainder of the multitude of strong archers from the sons of Kedar will be few, for the Lord, the God of Israel, has spoken it.”
verses.textLa: Et reliquiæ numeri sagittariorum fortium de filiis Cedar imminuentur: Dominus enim Deus Israel locutus est.

verses.textEn: The burden of the valley of vision. What does it mean to you, then, that each of you have even climbed to the rooftops?
verses.textLa: Onus vallis visionis. Quidnam quoque tibi est, quia ascendisti et tu omnis in tecta?

verses.textEn: Filled with clamor, a busy city, an exultant city: your dead have not been slain by the sword, nor did they die in battle.
verses.textLa: Clamoris plena, urbs frequens, civitas exultans: interfecti tui, non interfecti gladio, nec mortui in bello.

verses.textEn: All your leaders have fled together, and they have been bound by hardship. All who were found were chained together. They have fled far away.
verses.textLa: Cuncti principes tui fugerunt simul, dureque ligati sunt: omnes, qui inventi sunt, vincti sunt pariter, procul fugerunt.

verses.textEn: For this reason, I said: “Depart from me. I will weep bitterly. Make no attempt to console me, over the devastation of the daughter of my people.”
verses.textLa: Propterea dixi: Recedite a me, amare flebo: nolite incumbere ut consolemini me super vastitate filiæ populi mei.

verses.textEn: For it is a day of death, and of trampling, and of weeping to the Lord, the God of hosts, in the valley of vision: examining the wall and the magnificence above the mountain.
verses.textLa: Dies enim interfectionis, et conculcationis, et fletuum Domino Deo exercituum in valle visionis scrutans murum, et magnificus super montem.

verses.textEn: And Elam took up the quiver and the chariot of the horseman; and he stripped the wall of the shield.
verses.textLa: Et Ælam sumpsit pharetram, currum hominis equitis, et parietem nudavit clypeus.

verses.textEn: And your elect valleys will be filled with chariots, and the horsemen will position themselves at the gates.
verses.textLa: Et erunt electæ valles tuæ plenæ quadrigarum, et equites ponent sedes suas in porta.

verses.textEn: And the covering of Judah will be exposed, and in that day, you will see the weaponry of the forest house.
verses.textLa: Et revelabitur operimentum Iudæ, et videbis in die illa armamentarium domus saltus.

verses.textEn: And you will see breaches in the city of David, for these have been multiplied. But you have gathered together the waters of the lower fish-pool.
verses.textLa: Et scissuras civitatis David videbitis, quia multiplicatæ sunt: et congregastis aquas piscinæ inferioris,

verses.textEn: And you have numbered the houses of Jerusalem. And you have destroyed the houses in order to fortify the wall.
verses.textLa: et domos Ierusalem numerastis, et destruxistis domos ad muniendum murum.

verses.textEn: And you have made a pit between two walls for the waters of the ancient fish-pool. But you have not gazed upward to him who made it, and you have not considered, even from a distance, its Maker.
verses.textLa: Et lacum fecistis inter duos muros ad aquam piscinæ veteris: et non suspexistis ad eum, qui fecerat eam, et Operatorem eius de longe non vidistis.

verses.textEn: And in that day, the Lord, the God of hosts, will call to weeping and mourning, to baldness and the wearing of sackcloth.
verses.textLa: Et vocabit Dominus Deus exercituum in die illa ad fletum, et ad planctum, ad calvitium, et ad cingulum sacci:
verses.notes: This refers to the Day of Repentance, i.e. the Warning of Garabandal, when God will call everyone to repentance.

verses.textEn: But behold: gladness and rejoicing, the killing of calves and the slaughter of rams, the eating of meat and the drinking of wine: “Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we will die.”
verses.textLa: Et ecce gaudium et lætitia, occidere vitulos, et iugulare arietes, comedere carnes, et bibere vinum: Comedamus, et bibamus: cras enim moriemur.
verses.notes: This refers to the reaction to the Warning by persons who reject sorrow for their own sins and the gift of repentance. They will immerse themselves in food and drink and entertainment and sinful conduct, because they refuse to repent and so they know that their own end is near. Many will even mistakenly think that the end of the world is near.

verses.textEn: And the voice of the Lord of hosts was revealed in my ears: “Surely this iniquity will not be forgiven you, until you die,” says the Lord, the God of hosts.
verses.textLa: Et revelata est in auribus meis vox Domini exercituum. Si dimittetur iniquitas hæc vobis donec moriamini, dicit Dominus Deus exercituum.

verses.textEn: Thus says the Lord, the God of hosts: Go forth and enter to him who lives in the tabernacle, to Shebna, who is in charge of the temple, and you shall say to him:
verses.textLa: Hæc dicit Dominus Deus exercituum: Vade, ingredere ad eum, qui habitat in tabernaculo, ad Sobnam præpositum templi, et dices ad eum:

verses.textEn: “What are you here, or who are you claiming to be here? For you have hewn a sepulcher for yourself here. You have diligently hewn a memorial in a rock, as a tabernacle to yourself.
verses.textLa: Quid tu hic, aut quasi quis hic? Quia excidisti tibi hic sepulchrum, excidisti in excelso memoriale diligenter in petra, tabernaculum tibi.

verses.textEn: Behold, the Lord will cause you to be carried away, like a domesticated rooster, and he will remove you, like an outer garment.
verses.textLa: Ecce Dominus asportari te faciet, sicut asportatur gallus gallinaceus, et quasi amictum sic sublevabit te.
verses.notes: An ‘amictum’ is not any garment, but a cloak or coat or other outer garment. The verb sublevabit, in the context of an outer garment, refers to removing that garment.

verses.textEn: He will crown you with a crown of tribulation. He will toss you like a ball into a broad and spacious land. There you will die, and there the chariot of your glory will be, for it is a shame to the house of your Lord.”
verses.textLa: Coronas cornonabit te tribulatione, quasi pilam mittet te in terram latam et spatiosam: ibi morieris, et ibi erit currus gloriæ tuæ, ignominia domus Domini tui.

verses.textEn: And I will expel you from your station, and I will depose you from your ministry.
verses.textLa: Et expellam te de statione tua, et de ministerio tuo deponam te.

verses.textEn: And this shall be in that day: I will call my servant Eliakim, the son of Hilkiah.
verses.textLa: Et erit in die illa: Vocabo servum meum Eliacim filium Helciæ,

verses.textEn: And I will clothe him with your vestment, and I will strengthen him with your belt, and I will give your authority to his hand. And he shall be like a father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem and to the house of Judah.
verses.textLa: et induam illum tunica tua, et cingulo tuo confortabo eum, et potestatem tuam dabo in manu eius: et erit quasi pater habitantibus Ierusalem, et domui Iuda.

verses.textEn: And I will place the key of the house of David upon his shoulder. And when he opens, no one will close. And when he closes, no one will open.
verses.textLa: Et dabo clavem domus David super humerum eius: et aperiet, et non erit qui claudat: et claudet, et non erit qui aperiat.

verses.textEn: And I will fasten him like a peg in a trustworthy place. And he will be upon a throne of glory in the house of his father.
verses.textLa: Et figam illum paxillum in loco fideli, et erit in solium gloriæ domui patris eius.

verses.textEn: And they will suspend over him all the glory of his father’s house: various kinds of vessels and every little article, from the vessels of bowls even to every instrument of music.
verses.textLa: Et suspendent super eum omnem gloriam domus patris eius, vasorum diversa genera, omne vas parvulum a vasis craterarum usque ad omne vas musicorum.
verses.notes: The word ‘vas’ (also vasorum, vasis) has a broader meaning in Latin than ‘vessel’ or ‘container.’ It can refer to various kinds of utensils, equipment, tools, etc.

verses.textEn: In that day, says the Lord of hosts, the peg which was fastened in a trustworthy place shall be taken away. And he will be broken, and he will fall, and he will perish, along with all that had depended upon him, because the Lord has spoken it.
verses.textLa: In die illa dicit Dominus exercituum: Auferetur paxillus, qui fixus fuerat in loco fideli: et frangetur, et cadet, et peribit quod pependerat in eo, quia Dominus locutus est.
verses.notes: This passage refers to the end of the great Catholic monarch.

verses.textEn: The burden of Tyre. Wail, you ships of the sea! For the house, from which they were accustomed to go forth, has been laid waste. From the land of Kittim, this has been revealed to them.
verses.textLa: Onus Tyri. Ululate naves maris: quia vastata est domus, unde venire consueverant: de Terra Cethim revelatum est eis.

verses.textEn: Be silent, you inhabitants of the island! The merchants of Sidon, crossing over the sea, have filled you.
verses.textLa: Tacete qui habitatis in insula: negotiatores Sidonis transfretantes mare, repleverunt te.

verses.textEn: The offspring of the Nile is in the midst of many waters. The harvest of the river is her crop. And she has become the marketplace of the nations.
verses.textLa: In aquis multis semen Nili, messis fluminis fruges eius: et facta est negotiatio gentium.

verses.textEn: Be ashamed, O Sidon! For the sea speaks, the strength of the sea, saying: “I have not been in labor, and I have not given birth, and I have not raised young men, nor have I promoted the development of virgins.”
verses.textLa: Erubesce Sidon: ait enim mare: fortitudo maris dicens: Non parturivi, et non peperi, et non enutrivi iuvenes, nec ad incrementum perduxi virgines.

verses.textEn: When it has been heard in Egypt, they will be in anguish, when they hear of Tyre.
verses.textLa: Cum auditum fuerit in Ægypto, dolebunt cum audierint de Tiro:

verses.textEn: Cross over the seas. Wail, you inhabitants of the island!
verses.textLa: Transite maria, ululate qui habitatis in insula:

verses.textEn: Is this not your place, which from its earliest days has gloried in its antiquity? Her feet will lead her to a sojourn far away.
verses.textLa: Numquid non vestra hæc est, quæ gloriabatur a diebus pristinis in antiquitate sua? Ducent eam pedes sui longe ad peregrinandum.

verses.textEn: Who has made this plan against Tyre, which formerly was crowned, whose merchants were leaders, whose traders were illustrious on the earth?
verses.textLa: Quis cogitavit hoc super Tyrum quondam coronatam, cuius negotiatores principes, institores eius inclyti terræ?

verses.textEn: The Lord of hosts has planned this, so that he may tear down the arrogance of all glory, and may bring disgrace to all the illustrious of the earth.
verses.textLa: Dominus exercituum cogitavit hoc, ut detraheret superbiam omnis gloriæ, et ad ignominiam deduceret universos inclytos terræ.

verses.textEn: Cross through your land, as through a river, O daughter of the sea. You no longer have a belt.
verses.textLa: Transi terram tuam quasi flumen filia maris, non est cingulum ultra tibi.

verses.textEn: He has extended his hand over the sea. He has stirred up kingdoms. The Lord has given an order against Canaan, so that he may crush its strong.
verses.textLa: Manum suam extendit super mare, conturbavit regna: Dominus mandavit adversus Chanaan, ut contereret fortes eius,

verses.textEn: And he said: “You shall no longer increase so as to glory, while enduring calumny, O virgin daughter of Sidon. Rise up and set sail for Kittim; in that place, too, there will be no rest for you.”
verses.textLa: et dixit: Non adiicies ultra ut glorieris, calumniam sustinens virgo filia Sidonis: in Cethim consurgens transfreta, ibi quoque non erit requies tibi.

verses.textEn: Behold, the land of the Chaldeans: never before was there such a people! Assur founded it. They have led away its strong ones into captivity. They have dug under its houses. They have left it in ruins.
verses.textLa: Ecce terra Chaldæorum talis populus non fuit, Assur fundavit eam: in captivitatem traduxerunt robustos eius, suffoderunt domos eius, posuerunt eam in ruinam.

verses.textEn: Wail, you ships of the sea! For your strength has been devastated.
verses.textLa: Ululate naves maris, quia devastata est fortitudo vestra.

verses.textEn: And this shall be in that day: you, O Tyre, will be forgotten for seventy years, like the days of one king. Then, after seventy years, there will be, for Tyre, something like the canticle of a harlot.
verses.textLa: Et erit in die illa: In oblivione eris O Tyre septuaginta annis, sicut dies regis unius: post septuaginta autem annos erit Tyro quasi canticum meretricis.

verses.textEn: Take up a stringed instrument. Circulate through the city, you harlot who had been forgotten. Sing many canticles well, so that you may be remembered.
verses.textLa: Sume citharam, circui civitatem meretrix oblivioni tradita: bene cane, frequenta canticum ut memoria tui sit.

verses.textEn: And this shall be after seventy years: the Lord will visit Tyre, and he will lead her back to her profits. And she will fornicate again with all the kingdoms of the world upon the face of the earth.
verses.textLa: Et erit post septuaginta annos: Visitabit Dominus Tyrum, et reducet eam ad mercedes suas: et rursum fornicabitur cum universis regnis terræ super faciem terræ.

verses.textEn: And her businesses and her profits will be sanctified to the Lord. They will not be locked away and they will not be stored. For her business will be for those who will live in the presence of the Lord, so that they may eat until satisfied, and may be well-clothed even into old age.
verses.textLa: Et erunt negotiationes eius, et mercedes eius sanctificatæ Domino: non condentur, neque reponentur: quia his, qui habitaverint coram Domino, erit negotiatio eius, ut manducent in saturitatem, et vestiantur usque ad vetustatem.

verses.textEn: Behold, the Lord will lay waste to the earth, and he will strip it, and he will afflict its surface, and he will scatter its inhabitants.
verses.textLa: Ecce Dominus dissipabit terram, et nudabit eam, et affliget faciem eius, et disperget habitatores eius.

verses.textEn: And this shall be: as with the people, so with the priest; and as with the servant, so with his master; as with the handmaid, so with her mistress; as with the buyer, so with the seller; as with the lender, so with the borrower; as with the creditor, so with the debtor.
verses.textLa: Et erit sicut populus, sic sacerdos: et sicut servus, sic dominus eius: sicut ancilla, sic domina eius: sicut emens, sic ille qui vendit: sicut fœnerator, sic is qui mutuum accipit: sicut qui repetit, sic qui debet.

verses.textEn: The earth will be utterly devastated and utterly plundered. For the Lord has spoken this word.
verses.textLa: Dissipatione dissipabitur terra, et direptione prædabitur. Dominus enim locutus est verbum hoc.

verses.textEn: The earth mourned, and slipped away, and languished. The world slipped away; the loftiness of the people of the earth was weakened.
verses.textLa: Luxit, et defluxit terra, et infirmata est: defluxit orbis, infirmata est altitudo populi terræ.

verses.textEn: And the earth was corrupted by its inhabitants. For they have transgressed the laws, they have changed the ordinance, they have dissipated the everlasting covenant.
verses.textLa: Et terra infecta est ab habitatoribus suis: quia transgressi sunt leges, mutaverunt ius, dissipaverunt fœdus sempiternum.

verses.textEn: Because of this, a curse will devour the earth, and its inhabitants will sin. And for this reason, its caretakers will become crazed, and few men will be left behind.
verses.textLa: Propter hoc maledictio vorabit terram, et peccabunt habitatores eius: ideoque insanient cultores eius, et relinquentur homines pauci.

verses.textEn: The vintage has mourned. The vine has languished. All those who were rejoicing in their hearts have groaned.
verses.textLa: Luxit vindemia, infirmata est vitis, ingemuerunt omnes qui lætabantur corde.

verses.textEn: The gladness of the drums has ceased. The sound of rejoicing has quieted. The sweetness of stringed instruments has been silenced.
verses.textLa: Cessavit gaudium tympanorum, quievit sonitus lætantium, conticuit dulcedo citharæ.

verses.textEn: They will not drink wine with a song. The drink will be bitter to those who drink it.
verses.textLa: Cum cantico non bibent vinum: amara erit potio bibentibus illam.

verses.textEn: The city of vanity has been worn away. Every house has been closed up; no one enters.
verses.textLa: Attrita est civitas vanitatis, clausa est omnis domus nullo introeunte.

verses.textEn: There will be a clamor for wine in the streets. All rejoicing has been abandoned. The gladness of the earth has been carried away.
verses.textLa: Clamor erit super vino in plateis: deserta est omnia lætitia: translatum est gaudium terræ.

verses.textEn: Solitude is what remains in the city, and calamity will overwhelm its gates.
verses.textLa: Relicta est in urbe solitudo, et calamitas opprimet portas.

verses.textEn: For so shall it be in the midst of the earth, in the midst of the people: it is as if the few remaining olives are being shaken from the olive tree, and it is like a few clusters of grapes, when the grape harvest has already ended.
verses.textLa: Quia hæc erunt in medio terræ, in medio populorum: quomodo si paucæ olivæ, quæ remanserunt, excutiantur ex olea: et racemi, cum fuerit finita vindemia.

verses.textEn: These few shall lift up their voice and give praise. When the Lord will have been glorified, they will make a joyful noise from the sea.
verses.textLa: Hi levabunt vocem suam, atque laudabunt: cum glorificatus fuerit Dominus, hinnient de mari.

verses.textEn: Because of this, glorify the Lord in doctrine: the name of the Lord, the God of Israel, in the islands of the sea.
verses.textLa: Propter hoc in doctrinis glorificate Dominum: in insulis maris nomen Domini Dei Israel.

verses.textEn: From the ends of the earth, we have heard the praises of the glory of the Just One. And I said: “My secret is for myself! My secret is for myself! Woe to me! Those who would betray us have betrayed us, and they have betrayed us with the betrayal of transgression.”
verses.textLa: A finibus terræ laudes audivimus, gloriam Iusti. Et dixi: Secretum meum mihi, secretum meum mihi, væ mihi: prævaricantes prævaricati sunt, et prævaricatione transgressorum prævaricati sunt.

verses.textEn: Dread, and the pit, and the snare are over you, O inhabitant of the earth!
verses.textLa: Formido, et fovea, et laqueus super te, qui habitator es terræ.

verses.textEn: And this shall be: whoever will flee from the voice of dread will fall into the pit. And whoever will extricate himself from the pit will be caught in the snare. For the floodgates from above have been opened, and the foundations of the earth will be shaken.
verses.textLa: Et erit: Qui fugerit a voce formidinis, cadet in foveam: et qui se explicaverit de fovea, tenebitur laqueo: quia cataractæ de excelsis apertæ sunt, et concutientur fundamenta terræ.

verses.textEn: The earth will be utterly broken! The earth will be utterly crushed! The earth will be utterly shaken!
verses.textLa: Confractione confringetur terra, contritione conteretur terra, commotione commovebitur terra,

verses.textEn: The earth will stagger greatly, like a drunken man, and will be carried away, like the tent of a single night. And its iniquity will be heavy upon it, and it will fall and not rise up again.
verses.textLa: agitatione agitabitur terra sicut ebrius, et auferetur quasi tabernaculum unius noctis: et gravabit eam iniquitas sua, et corruet, et non adiiciet ut resurgat.

verses.textEn: And this shall be: in that day, the Lord will visit upon the armies of the sky above, and upon the kings of the earth who are on the ground.
verses.textLa: Et erit: In die illa visitabit Dominus super militiam cæli in excelso: et super reges terræ, qui sunt super terram.

verses.textEn: And they will be gathered together like the gathering of one bundle into a pit. And they will be enclosed in that place, as in a prison. And after many days, they will be visited.
verses.textLa: Et congregabuntur in congregatione unius fascis in lacum, et claudentur ibi in carcere: et post multos dies visitabuntur.

verses.textEn: And the moon will be ashamed, and the sun will be confounded, when the Lord of hosts will reign on mount Zion and in Jerusalem, and when he will have been glorified in the sight of his elders.
verses.textLa: Et erubescet luna, et confundetur sol, cum regnaverit Dominus exercituum in monte Sion, et in Ierusalem, et in conspectu senum suorum fuerit glorificatus.

verses.textEn: O Lord, you are my God! I will exalt you, and I will confess your name. For you have accomplished miracles. Your plan, from antiquity, is faithful. Amen.
verses.textLa: Domine Deus meus es tu, exaltabo te, et confitebor nomini tuo: quoniam fecisti mirabilia, cogitationes antiquas fideles: Amen.

verses.textEn: For you have appointed a city as a tomb, a strong city for ruination, a house of foreigners: so that it may not be a city, and so that it may not be rebuilt forever.
verses.textLa: Quia posuisti civitatem in tumulum, urbem fortem in ruinam, domum alienorum: ut non sit civitas, et in sempiternum non ædificetur.
verses.notes: The word ‘tumulum’ refers to type of mound of earth or a small hill used as a tomb.

verses.textEn: Concerning this, a strong people will praise you; a city with a robust people will fear you.
verses.textLa: Super hoc laudabit te populus fortis, civitas gentium robustarum timebit te.

verses.textEn: For you have been the strength of the poor, the strength of the indigent in his tribulation, a refuge from the whirlwind, a shadow from the heat. For the spirit of the mighty is like a whirlwind striking against a wall.
verses.textLa: Quia factus es fortitudo pauperi, fortitudo egeno in tribulatione sua: spes a turbine, umbraculum ab æstu: spiritus enim robustorum quasi turbo impellens parietem.

verses.textEn: You will bring low the uprising of foreigners, just as heat brings thirst. And like heat under a torrential cloud, you will cause the offshoot of the strong to wither away.
verses.textLa: Sicut æstus in siti, tumultum alienorum humiliabis: et quasi calore sub nube torrente propaginem fortium marcescere facies.

verses.textEn: And the Lord of hosts will cause all the peoples on this mountain to feast on fatness, to feast on wine, a fatness full of marrow, a purified wine.
verses.textLa: Et faciet Dominus exercituum omnibus populis in monte hoc convivium pinguium, convivium vindemiæ, pinguium medullatorum, vindemiæ defæcatæ.

verses.textEn: And he will cast down violently, on this mountain, the face of the chains, with which all peoples had been bound, and the net, with which all nations had been covered.
verses.textLa: Et præcipitabit in monte isto faciem vinculi colligati super omnes populos, et telam quam orditus est super omnes nationes.

verses.textEn: He will violently cast down death forever. And the Lord God will take away the tears from every face, and he will take away the disgrace of his people from the entire earth. For the Lord has spoken it.
verses.textLa: Præcipitabit mortem in sempiternum: et auferet Dominus Deus lacrymam ab omni facie, et opprobrium populi sui auferet de universa terra: quia Dominus locutus est.

verses.textEn: And they will say in that day: “Behold, this is our God! We have waited for him, and he will save us. This is the Lord! We have endured for him. We will exult and rejoice in his salvation.”
verses.textLa: Et dicet in die illa: Ecce Deus noster iste, expectavimus eum, et salvabit nos: iste Dominus, sustinuimus eum, exultabimus, et lætabimur in salutari eius.

verses.textEn: For the hand of the Lord will rest upon this mountain. And Moab will be trampled under him, just as stubble is worn away by a wagon.
verses.textLa: Quia requiescet manus Domini in monte isto: et triturabitur Moab sub eo, sicuti teruntur paleæ in plaustro.

verses.textEn: And he will extend his hands under him, like a swimmer extending his hands to swim. And he will bring down his glory with a clap of his hands.
verses.textLa: Et extendet manus suas sub eo, sicut extendit natans ad natandum: et humiliabit gloriam eius cum allisione manuum eius.

verses.textEn: And the fortifications of your sublime walls will fall, and be brought low, and be torn down to the ground, even to the dust.
verses.textLa: Et munimenta sublimium murorum tuorum concident, et humiliabuntur, et detrahentur in terram usque ad pulverem.

verses.textEn: In that day, this canticle will be sung in the land of Judah. Within it will be set the city of our strength: Zion, a savior, a wall with a bulwark.
verses.textLa: In die illa cantabitur canticum istud in terra Iuda: Urbs fortitudinis nostræ Sion salvator, ponetur in ea murus et antemurale.

verses.textEn: Open the gates, and let the just people who guard the truth enter.
verses.textLa: Aperite portas, et ingrediatur gens iusta, custodiens veritatem.

verses.textEn: The old error has gone away. You will serve peace: peace, for we have hoped in you.
verses.textLa: Vetus error abiit: servabis pacem: pacem, quia in te speravimus.

verses.textEn: You have trusted in the Lord for all eternity, in the Lord God almighty forever.
verses.textLa: Sperastis in Domino in sæculis æternis, in Domino Deo forti in perpetuum.

verses.textEn: For he will bend down those living in the heights. He will bring low the lofty city. He will lower it, even to the ground. He will tear it down, even to the dust.
verses.textLa: Quia incurvabit habitantes in excelso, civitatem sublimem humiliabit. Humiliabit eam usque ad terram, detrahet eam usque ad pulverem.

verses.textEn: The foot will tread it down: the feet of the poor, the steps of the indigent.
verses.textLa: Conculcabit eam pes, pedes pauperis, gressus egenorum.

verses.textEn: The path of the just is upright; the difficult path of the just is right to walk in.
verses.textLa: Semita iusti recta est, rectus callis iusti ad ambulandum.

verses.textEn: And in the path of your judgments, O Lord, we have endured for you. Your name and your remembrance are the desire of the soul.
verses.textLa: Et in semita iudiciorum tuorum Domine sustinuimus te: nomen tuum, et memoriale tuum in desiderio animæ.

verses.textEn: My soul has desired you in the night. But I will also watch for you with my spirit, in my inmost heart, from the morning. When you accomplish your judgments upon the earth, the inhabitants of the world will learn justice.
verses.textLa: Anima mea desideravit te in nocte: sed et spiritu meo in præcordiis meis de mane vigilabo ad te. Cum feceris iudicia tua in terra, iustitiam discent habitatores orbis.

verses.textEn: Let us take pity on the impious one, but he will not learn justice. In the land of the holy ones, he has done iniquity, and so he will not see the glory of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Misereamur impio, et non discet iustitiam: in terra sanctorum iniqua gessit, et non videbit gloriam Domini.

verses.textEn: Lord, let your hand be exalted, and let them not see it. May the envious people see and be confounded. And may fire devour your enemies.
verses.textLa: Domine exaltetur manus tua, et non videant: videant, et confundantur zelantes populi: et ignis hostes tuos devoret.

verses.textEn: Lord, you will give us peace. For all our works have been wrought for us by you.
verses.textLa: Domine dabis pacem nobis: omnia enim opera nostra operatus es nobis.

verses.textEn: O Lord our God, other lords have possessed us apart from you, but in you alone let us remember your name.
verses.textLa: Domine Deus noster, possederunt nos domini absque te, tantum in te recordemur nominis tui.

verses.textEn: Let not the dead live; let not the giants rise up again. For this reason, you have visited and destroyed them, and you have perished all remembrance of them.
verses.textLa: Morientes non vivant, gigantes non resurgant: propterea visitasti et contrivisti eos, et perdidisti omnem memoriam eorum.

verses.textEn: You have been lenient to the people, O Lord, lenient to the people. But have you been glorified? You have removed all the limits of the earth.
verses.textLa: Indulsisti genti Domine, indulsisti genti: numquid glorificatus es? Elongasti omnes terminos terræ.

verses.textEn: Lord, they have sought you in anguish. Your doctrine was with them, amid the tribulation of murmuring.
verses.textLa: Domine in angustia requisierunt te, in tribulatione murmuris doctrina tua eis.

verses.textEn: Like a woman who has conceived and is approaching the time for delivery, who, in anguish, cries out in her pains, so have we become before your face, O Lord.
verses.textLa: Sicut quæ concipit, cum appropinquaverit ad partum, dolens clamat in doloribus suis: sic facti sumus a facie tua Domine.

verses.textEn: We have conceived, and it is as if we were in labor, but we have given birth to wind. We have not brought forth salvation on the earth. For this reason, the inhabitants of the earth have not fallen.
verses.textLa: Concepimus, et quasi parturivimus, et peperimus spiritum: salutes non fecimus in terra, ideo non ceciderunt habitatores terræ.

verses.textEn: Your dead shall live. My slain will rise again. Be awakened, and give praise, you who live in the dust! For your dew is the dew of the light, and you shall be dragged down to the land of the giants, to ruination.
verses.textLa: Vivent mortui tui, interfecti mei resurgent: expergiscimini, et laudate qui habitatis in pulvere: quia ros lucis ros tuus, et terram gigantum detrahes in ruinam.

verses.textEn: Go, my people! Enter your chambers. Close your doors behind you. Conceal yourselves for a very brief time, until the indignation has passed over you.
verses.textLa: Vade populus meus, intra in cubicula tua, claude ostia tua super te, abscondere modicum ad momentum, donec pertranseat indignatio.

verses.textEn: For behold, the Lord will go forth from his place, so that he may visit the iniquity of each inhabitant of the earth against him. And the earth will reveal its blood, and it will no longer cover its slain.
verses.textLa: Ecce enim Dominus egredietur de loco suo, ut visitet iniquitatem habitatoris terræ contra eum: et revelabit terra sanguinem suum, et non operiet ultra interfectos suos.

verses.textEn: In that day, the Lord will visit, with his harsh and great and strong sword, against Leviathan, the barred serpent, and against Leviathan, the twisted serpent, and he will slay the whale that is in the sea.
verses.textLa: In die illa visitabit Dominus in gladio suo duro, et grandi, et forti, super Leviathan serpentem vectem, et super Leviathan serpentem tortuosum, et occidet cetum, qui in mari est.

verses.textEn: In that day, the vineyard of pure wine will sing to them.
verses.textLa: In die illa vinea meri cantabit ei.

verses.textEn: I am the Lord, who watches over it. I will suddenly give drink to it. I will watch over it, night and day, lest perhaps someone visit against it.
verses.textLa: Ego Dominus, qui servo eam, repente propinabo ei: ne forte visitetur contra eam, nocte et die servo eam.

verses.textEn: Indignation is not mine. Who will be a thorn and a brier to me in battle? I will advance against them. I set them on fire together.
verses.textLa: Indignatio non est mihi: quis dabit me spinam et veprem in prælio? Gradiar super eam, succendam eam pariter.

verses.textEn: Or will he, instead, take hold of my strength? Will he make peace with me? Will she make peace with me?
verses.textLa: An potius tenebit fortitudinem meam, faciet pacem mihi, pacem faciet mihi?
verses.notes: The word ‘spinam’ is feminine and the word ‘veprem’ is masculine, hence the translation: “will he…will she….” The spine represents the false prophetess of the Book of Revelation, and the brier represents the Antichrist.

verses.textEn: As they advance with violence against Jacob, Israel will flourish and spring forth, and they will fill the face of the world with offspring.
verses.textLa: Qui ingrediuntur impetu ad Iacob, florebit et germinabit Israel, et implebunt faciem orbis semine.

verses.textEn: Has he struck him with the scourge that he himself used to strike others? Or has he killed in the manner that he himself used to kill his victims?
verses.textLa: Numquid iuxta plagam percutientis se percussit eum? Aut sicut occidit interfectos eius, sic occisus est?

verses.textEn: You will judge this by comparing one measure to another, when he has been cast out. He has decided this, by his stern spirit, for the day of heat.
verses.textLa: In mensura contra mensuram, cum abiecta fuerit, iudicabis eam: meditatus est in spiritu suo duro per diem æstus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, concerning this, the iniquity of the house of Jacob will be forgiven. And this is the reward of all: that their sin be taken away, when he will have made all the stones of the altar to be like crushed cinders. For the sacred groves and the shrines shall not stand.
verses.textLa: Idcirco super hoc dimittetur iniquitas domui Iacob: et iste omnis fructus ut auferatur peccatum eius, cum posuerit omnes lapides altaris sicut lapides cineris allisos, non stabunt luci et delubra.

verses.textEn: For the fortified city will be desolate. The shining city will be abandoned and will be left behind like a desert. In that place, the calf will pasture, and in that place, he will lie down, and he will feed from its summits.
verses.textLa: Civitas enim munita desolata erit, speciosa relinquetur, et dimittetur quasi desertum: ibi pascetur vitulus, et ibi accubabit, et consumet summitates eius.

verses.textEn: Its harvest will be crushed by dryness. Women will arrive and teach it, for it is not a wise people. Because of this, he who made it will not take pity on it, and he who formed it will not spare it.
verses.textLa: In siccitate messes illius conterentur, mulieres venientes, et docentes eam: non est enim populus sapiens, propterea non miserebitur eius, qui fecit eum: et qui formavit eum, non parcet ei.

verses.textEn: And this shall be: in that day, the Lord will strike, from the channel of the river, even to the torrent of Egypt. And you shall be gathered together, one by one, O sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: Et erit: In die illa percutiet Dominus ab alveo fluminis usque ad torrentem Ægypti, et vos congregabimini unus et unus filii Israel.

verses.textEn: And this shall be: in that day, a noise will be made with a great trumpet. And those who had been lost will approach from the land of the Assyrians, with those who had been outcasts in the land of Egypt. And they will adore the Lord, on the holy mountain, in Jerusalem.
